# Airboat

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Air_boat.jpg/220px-
Air_boat.jpg)](/wiki/File:Air_boat.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Air_boat.jpg "Enlarge")

An airboat

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Airboating_1%2C_Everglades%2C_FL%2C_jjron_31.03.2012.jpg/220px-
Airboating_1%2C_Everglades%2C_FL%2C_jjron_31.03.2012.jpg)](/wiki/File:Airboating_1,_Everglades,_FL,_jjron_31.03.2012.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Airboating_1,_Everglades,_FL,_jjron_31.03.2012.jpg "Enlarge")

Airboating is a popular [ecotourism](/wiki/Ecotourism "Ecotourism") attraction
in the Florida [Everglades](/wiki/Everglades "Everglades")

An **airboat** , also known as a **fanboat** , is a flat-bottomed
[watercraft](/wiki/Watercraft "Watercraft") propelled by an aircraft-type
[propeller](/wiki/Propeller_\(aircraft\) "Propeller \(aircraft\)") and powered
by either an aircraft or automotive engine.[note 1] They are commonly used for
fishing, bowfishing, hunting, and [ecotourism](/wiki/Ecotourism "Ecotourism").

Airboats are a very popular means of transportation in marshy and/or shallow
areas where a standard inboard or outboard engine with a submerged propeller
would be impractical, most notably in the Florida
[Everglades](/wiki/Everglades "Everglades") but also in the [Indian River
Lagoon](/wiki/Indian_River_Lagoon "Indian River Lagoon"), the
[Kissimmee](/wiki/Kissimmee "Kissimmee") and [St. Johns](/wiki/St._Johns_River
"St. Johns River") rivers, and the [Mekong River](/wiki/Mekong_River "Mekong
River") and [Delta](/wiki/Mekong_Delta "Mekong Delta"), as well as the
[Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana") [bayous](/wiki/Bayou "Bayou") and
[Mesopotamian Marshes](/wiki/Mesopotamian_Marshes "Mesopotamian Marshes").

## Overview[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Overview")]

The characteristic flat-bottomed design of the airboat, in conjunction with
the fact that there are no operating parts below the
[waterline](/wiki/Waterline "Waterline"), allows for easy navigation through
shallow swamps and marshes; in canals, rivers, and lakes; and on ice and
frozen lakes. This design also makes it ideal for flood and ice rescue
operations.[1][2]

The airboat is pushed forward by the propeller, which produces a rearward
column of air behind it. The resulting [prop wash](/wiki/Prop_wash "Prop
wash") averages 150 miles per hour (241 km/h). Steering is accomplished by
diverting that column of air left or right as it passes across the rudders,
which the pilot controls via a "stick" located on the operator's left side.
Overall steering and control is a function of water current, wind, water
depth, and propeller thrust. Airboats are very fast compared to comparably-
sized [motorboats](/wiki/Motorboat "Motorboat"): commercial airboats generally
sail at speeds of around 35 miles per hour (30 kn) and modified airboats can
go as fast as 135 miles per hour (117 kn).[3]

Stopping and reversing direction are dependent upon high operator skill, since
airboats do not have brakes.[3] They are incapable of traveling in reverse,
unless equipped with a [reversible propeller](/wiki/Reversible_propeller
"Reversible propeller"). Some designs use a clam shell reversing device
intended for braking or backing up very short distances but these systems are
not commonly used.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The operator and passengers, are typically seated in elevated seats that allow
visibility over swamp vegetation. High visibility lets the operator and
passengers see floating objects, stumps and other submerged obstacles, and
animals in the boat's path.[1][4]

In the United States, a typical good-quality airboat costs between
$33,000[5][note 2] and $70,000.[6] In a developing country like Iraq, however,
an airboat can be purchased for as little as 2.5 million [Iraqi
dinars](/wiki/Iraqi_dinar "Iraqi dinar"), or $2,147.[7] In spite of their high
cost, airboats are very widely used by civilians and tour operators: there are
12,164 airboats, 1,025 of them commercial, in Florida alone as of December
2017.[3] Airboats are widely used in other [Gulf Coast](/wiki/Gulf_Coast "Gulf
Coast") states, especially [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana"), but they
can be found in rivers, marshes, and icy areas around the world, from
[Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska "Nebraska")[8] to [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia
"Siberia").

### Soviet airboats and
aerosleds[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Soviet airboats and aerosleds")]

Main article: [Aerosled](/wiki/Aerosled "Aerosled")

Airboats and airboat-like craft have been used in the [Soviet
Union](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet Union") and its successor states since the
[Second World War](/wiki/Second_World_War "Second World War") and possibly
earlier. Some true airboats—vessels that operated entirely in the water—were
used by the Soviet military in [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War
II"). These true airboats include the
[NKL-5](/w/index.php?title=NKL-5&action=edit&redlink=1 "NKL-5 \(page does not
exist\)"), a 1,200 kilograms (2,600 lb) WWII armed boat reportedly capable of
speeds up to 60 kilometres per hour (37 mph; 32 kn).[9] However, most Soviet
airboats are [aerosleds](/wiki/Aerosled "Aerosled") (referred to as
"aerosanis" in Russian). An aerosled is an aircraft propeller driven
amphibious vehicle best described as a hybrid of a sled, airboat, and [ground
effect vehicle](/wiki/Ground_effect_vehicle "Ground effect vehicle").
Thousands of aerosleds were used as cargo and passenger vehicles in
[Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia"), where they excelled because they could
cope equally well with the icy Siberian winter and the muddy, marshy
conditions of [Rasputitsa](/wiki/Rasputitsa "Rasputitsa") season (similar to
the American [mud season](/wiki/Mud_season "Mud season")), when raw or thawing
snow makes travel by road impossible. Aerosleds are still in use today.[10]
The [Tupolev A-3 Aerosledge](/wiki/Tupolev_A-3_Aerosledge "Tupolev A-3
Aerosledge") is a quintessential example of this type of vehicle; it can reach
speeds of up to 120 kilometers per hour (74.6 mph) on snow and 65 km/h (40.4
mph) on water.[11]

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: History")]

The earliest airboats date to 1915, when they were used by the [British
Army](/wiki/British_Army "British Army") in the World War I [Mesopotamian
Campaign](/wiki/Mesopotamian_Campaign "Mesopotamian Campaign").[12] However,
airboats were not widely used by civilians until the 1940s and 1950s,
following the invention of a more practical airboat design in 1946 in
[Utah](/wiki/Utah "Utah").[13]

### Antecedents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Antecedents")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Ugly_Duckling.jpg/220px-
Ugly_Duckling.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ugly_Duckling.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ugly_Duckling.jpg "Enlarge")

Dr. Alexander Graham Bell with his aircraft engine test boat and airboat
ancestor, the _Ugly Duckling_

The earliest ancestors of the airboat were waterborne vehicles for testing
aircraft engines. The oldest ancestor of the airboat was the _Ugly Duckling_ ,
an aircraft propeller testing vehicle built in 1905 in [Nova
Scotia](/wiki/Nova_Scotia "Nova Scotia"), Canada by a team led by Dr.
[Alexander Graham Bell](/wiki/Alexander_Graham_Bell "Alexander Graham Bell").
_Ugly Duckling_ was a [catamaran](/wiki/Catamaran "Catamaran")-type boat
propelled by an "aerial propeller" hooked up to a water-cooled aircraft engine
weighing 2,500 pounds (1,100 kg). The makeshift raft-like vessel was unable to
obtain a speed faster than 4 miles per hour (3.5 [knots](/wiki/Knot_\(unit\)
"Knot \(unit\)")), though the "rapid rotation of the propeller" led Dr. Bell
to believe that the vessel could have had a theoretical top speed of "thirty
or forty miles an hour," comparable to some modern airboats, if drag was
completely eliminated.[14] Brazilian aviation pioneer [Santos
Dumont](/wiki/Santos_Dumont "Santos Dumont") built a similar catamaran vessel
for testing an aircraft engine in 1907, which he termed a
[hydrofoil](/wiki/Hydrofoil "Hydrofoil").[15]

The [Tellier
brothers](/w/index.php?title=Tellier_brothers&action=edit&redlink=1 "Tellier
brothers \(page does not exist\)"), French aviation pioneers, made major steps
towards modern airboats with their 1907 speedboat _La Rapière II_ (_Rapier
II_). _La Rapière II_ was an 8 metres (26 ft) long mahogany speedboat powered
by an above water aircraft propeller hooked up to a 20 hp 4 cylinder [Panhard-
Levassor](/wiki/Panhard-Levassor "Panhard-Levassor") engine. The boat was
steered by a conventional rudder in the water, which was hooked up to a ship's
wheel.[16] _La Rapière II_ could achieve speeds of up to 26 kilometres per
hour (16 mph; 14 kn) with two people on board and 25 kilometres per hour (16
mph; 13 kn) with 3-4 people on board.[15]

### Early airboats[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Early airboats")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Glisseur_automobile_de_l%27arm%C3%A9e_anglaise_en_M%C3%A9sopotamie.jpg/220px-
Glisseur_automobile_de_l%27arm%C3%A9e_anglaise_en_M%C3%A9sopotamie.jpg)](/wiki/File:Glisseur_automobile_de_l%27arm%C3%A9e_anglaise_en_M%C3%A9sopotamie.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Glisseur_automobile_de_l%27arm%C3%A9e_anglaise_en_M%C3%A9sopotamie.jpg
"Enlarge")

Early [British Army](/wiki/British_Army "British Army") airboats in
[Mesopotamia](/wiki/Mesopotamia "Mesopotamia") in 1918

The earliest true airboats date to 1915. The [British Army](/wiki/British_Army
"British Army") used airboats, which they referred to as Lambert "Hydro-
Glisseurs",[note 3] in the [Mesopotamian Campaign](/wiki/Mesopotamian_Campaign
"Mesopotamian Campaign") of the [First World War](/wiki/First_World_War "First
World War"). These "Hydro-Glisseurs" were small, flat-bottomed
[hydroplanes](/wiki/Hydroplane_\(boat\) "Hydroplane \(boat\)") with [metal-
plated](/wiki/Ironclad "Ironclad") wooden hulls propelled by a large aircraft
fan that allowed them to reach speeds of up to 55 miles per hour (48 kn).[17]
They were primarily used for reconnaissance on the [Tigris
River](/wiki/Tigris_River "Tigris River").[12] The first of these airboats, HG
1 _Ariel_ , was constructed using the engine and propeller of a wrecked [Royal
Australian Air Force](/wiki/Royal_Australian_Air_Force "Royal Australian Air
Force") [Farman MF.7](/wiki/Farman_MF.7 "Farman MF.7") biplane and was
provided to the forces in Mesopotamia by the [British Raj](/wiki/British_Raj
"British Raj").[18] Following _Ariel_ 's successful deployment in the campaign
upriver to [Kut](/wiki/Kut "Kut") in 1915-1916, Britain ordered seven purpose-
built airboats from [Charles de Lambert](/wiki/Charles_de_Lambert_\(aviator\)
"Charles de Lambert \(aviator\)")'s eponymous company _De Lambert_. Eight of
these vessels were in operation in 1917, increasing to nine by the 1918
[Armistice](/wiki/Armistice_of_11_November_1918 "Armistice of 11 November
1918").[19] A dedicated repair slipway for these boats was built at the Motor
Repair Dockyard in [Baghdad](/wiki/Baghdad "Baghdad"), indicating both their
importance to the British war effort and the difficulty of maintaining
them.[19]:67-8

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/71/ScientificAmerican1917-11-03.jpg/220px-
ScientificAmerican1917-11-03.jpg)](/wiki/File:ScientificAmerican1917-11-03.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:ScientificAmerican1917-11-03.jpg "Enlarge")

A 1917 _[Scientific American](/wiki/Scientific_American "Scientific
American")_ cover depicting a British Army airboat on the [Tigris
River](/wiki/Tigris_River "Tigris River") in Iraq

Following the war, Lambert airboats were used as ferries on the shallow waters
of the [upper Yangtze River](/wiki/Upper_Yangtze_River "Upper Yangtze River"),
on the [Huangpu River](/wiki/Huangpu_River "Huangpu River"), and elsewhere.
Like their military counterparts, these airboats were manufactured in France,
though they were assembled in [Shanghai](/wiki/Shanghai "Shanghai"). They had
[drafts](/wiki/Draft_\(hull\) "Draft \(hull\)") of only seven inches and could
cruise at up to 32 miles per hour (28 kn). Lambert airboats were also used
widely on the upper [Missouri River](/wiki/Missouri_River "Missouri River")
and on the marshes of the [Florida Everglades](/wiki/Florida_Everglades
"Florida Everglades").[17]

[Farman Aircraft](/wiki/Farman_Aircraft "Farman Aircraft"), the company that
built the engines for WWI military airboats, began producing civilian airboats
in the 1920s. It marketed airboats for use as [water taxis](/wiki/Water_taxi
"Water taxi") and as light cargo vessels or [patrol boats](/wiki/Patrol_boat
"Patrol boat") for French colonial governments. Its airboats sold for 25,000
to 50,000 [francs](/wiki/Francs "Francs") depending on the model, a price that
proved too steep for potential buyers; the company pulled out of the boat
business by the end of the 1920s.[15]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Vintage_Farman_airboat.jpg/220px-
Vintage_Farman_airboat.jpg)](/wiki/File:Vintage_Farman_airboat.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Vintage_Farman_airboat.jpg "Enlarge")

[Farman](/wiki/Farman "Farman") airboat prototype _Le Ricocheur_ in 1924. She
was capable of speeds of up to 125 km/h (67.5 [knots](/wiki/Knot_\(unit\)
"Knot \(unit\)"))

These early European airboats were significantly different from their modern
counterparts. Compared to the airboats of today, early European airboats
tended to be somewhat larger, had higher [freeboards](/wiki/Freeboard
"Freeboard"), and lacked a protective cage surrounding the propeller.[20] They
also had a different steering mechanism: early airboats were steered with a
[rudder](/wiki/Rudder "Rudder") in the water controlled by a [steering
wheel](/wiki/Steering_wheel "Steering wheel") with throttle control provided
by a [gas pedal](/wiki/Gas_pedal "Gas pedal"), like an
[automobile](/wiki/Automobile "Automobile").[19] More modern airboats use an
[air rudder](/wiki/Rudder#Aircraft_rudders "Rudder") controlled with a
[joystick](/wiki/Joystick "Joystick") for steering.

[Glenn Curtiss](/wiki/Glenn_Curtiss "Glenn Curtiss") is credited with building
a type of airboat in 1920 to help facilitate his hobby of bow and arrow
hunting in the Florida backwoods. The millionaire, who later went on to
develop the cities of [Hialeah](/wiki/Hialeah "Hialeah") and
[Miami](/wiki/Miami "Miami"), combined his talents in the fields of aviation
and design to facilitate his hobby, and the end result was _Scooter_ , a
6-passenger, closed-cabin, propeller-driven boat powered by an aircraft engine
that allowed it to slip through wetlands at 50 miles per hour (43 kn).[21][22]

### First American
airboats[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: First American airboats")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Early_airboat.jpg/220px-
Early_airboat.jpg)](/wiki/File:Early_airboat.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Early_airboat.jpg "Enlarge")

Cecil Williams operating _Alligator I_ , one of the first airboats, at [Bear
River Migratory Bird Refuge](/wiki/Bear_River_Migratory_Bird_Refuge "Bear
River Migratory Bird Refuge") in 1946

Airboats first became popular in the United States following the invention of
an airboat more suitable for wetland use in 1943 by Cecil Williams, Leo Young,
and G. Hortin Jensen.[23] Their boat, developed and used near [Brigham City,
Utah](/wiki/Brigham_City,_Utah "Brigham City, Utah"), is often erroneously
considered the first airboat. At the [Bear River Migratory Bird
Refuge](/wiki/Bear_River_Migratory_Bird_Refuge "Bear River Migratory Bird
Refuge") in northern Utah, Cecil S. Williams and G. Hortin Jensen sought a
solution to the problem of conducting avian [botulism](/wiki/Botulism
"Botulism") studies in the shallow, marshy hinterlands. By installing a
40-horsepower [Continental](/wiki/Continental_Motors,_Inc. "Continental
Motors, Inc.") aircraft engine, purchased for $99.50, on a flat-bottomed
12-foot long aluminum boat, they built one of the world's first modern
airboats. Their airboat, pictured at left, had no seat, so the skipper was
forced to kneel in the boat. They dubbed it the _Alligator I_ as a response to
a joking comment from [US Fish and Wildlife
Service](/wiki/US_Fish_and_Wildlife_Service "US Fish and Wildlife Service")
headquarters that they should "get an [alligator](/wiki/Alligator "Alligator")
from Louisiana, saddle up and ride the critter during their botulism
studies."[24] Their airboat was the first to use an air rudder (a rudder
directing the propeller exhaust rather than the water), a major improvement in
modern airboat design.[13]

The purpose of Williams, Young, and Jensen's airboat was to help preserve and
protect bird populations and animal life at the world's largest migratory game
bird refuge.[25] The Bear River Migratory Bird Refuge near [Brigham City,
Utah](/wiki/Brigham_City,_Utah "Brigham City, Utah") is a wetlands oasis amid
the [Great Basin Desert](/wiki/Great_Basin_Desert "Great Basin Desert") and an
essential stopping point for birds migrating across North America. The need
for a practical way to navigate a challenging environment of wetlands, shallow
water, and thick mud helped inspire Williams, Young, and Jensen to create the
flat-bottom airboat, which they initially called an "air thrust boat."[13]
Designs and subsequent improvements and practical use of the air thrust boats
appears to have been a collaborative effort. LeeRue Allen, who worked at the
Refuge since 1936 appears to have also been involved and helped to document a
history of the events.[26]

Many of the early airboats built at the refuge in Utah were shipped to
Florida. Early records show it cost roughly $1,600 to build a boat, including
the engine.[13]

Other people—all Floridians—who are sometimes claimed to have invented the
airboat include frog hunter Johnny Lamb, who allegedly built a 75 horsepower
airboat in 1933 he called the "whooshmobile" and
[Chokoloskee](/wiki/Chokoloskee "Chokoloskee") Gladesmen Ernest and Willard
Yates, who claim to have built an airboat in 1935 they steered via
[reins](/wiki/Reins "Reins") attached to a crude wooden rudder.[27]

Over the years a variety of designs were tried and through trial-and-error,
the standard design used today arose: an open, flat bottom boat with an engine
mounted on the back, the driver sitting in an elevated position, and a cage to
protect the propeller from objects flying into them.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/87/Hydrilla_verticillata_collection_LakeSeminoleFL.jpg/170px-
Hydrilla_verticillata_collection_LakeSeminoleFL.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hydrilla_verticillata_collection_LakeSeminoleFL.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hydrilla_verticillata_collection_LakeSeminoleFL.jpg "Enlarge")

The [US Army Corps of Engineers](/wiki/US_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "US Army
Corps of Engineers") uses an airboat to collect herbicide-resistant
[hydrilla](/wiki/Hydrilla "Hydrilla") from [Lake Seminole](/wiki/Lake_Seminole
"Lake Seminole") in northern Florida

## Manufacture and
design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section:
Manufacture and design")]

Airboat manufacturers tend to be small, family run businesses that assemble
built-to-order boats. Most airboats are manufactured in the United States,
although they are also built in [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia"),[28],
[Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy"),[29] [Finland](/wiki/Finland "Finland"),[2][30]
[Japan](/wiki/Japan "Japan"),[31] [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"),[4]
and elsewhere. Prior to 1950, most airboats were manufactured in France by
companies and individuals such as [Farman](/wiki/Farman "Farman"), [De
Lambert](/wiki/Charles_de_Lambert_\(aviator\) "Charles de Lambert
\(aviator\)"), and [René Couzinet](/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Couzinet "René
Couzinet").[15]

Modern, commercially manufactured airboat hulls are made of aluminum or
fiberglass. The choice of material is determined by the type of terrain in
which the vessel will be operated; airboats intended for use in icy conditions
will have sturdier polymer coated aluminum hulls while airboats intended for
use in marshes will have lighter fiberglass hulls, for instance.[5] Standard
hunt/trail boats are 10 feet (3.0 m) long with a two- to three-passenger
capacity. Tour boats can be much larger, accommodating 18 passengers or
more.[3]

Engines are either an air-cooled, 4- or 6-cylinder aircraft or water-cooled,
large-displacement, V8 automotive engine, ranging from 50 to over 600
[hp](/wiki/Hp "Hp"). Automotive engines tend to be less expensive due to
readily-available replacement parts and less expensive [high
octane](/wiki/Octane_number "Octane number") automotive gas. Since an opposed,
4- or 6-cylinder (O4 or O6) aircraft powerplant contains fewer moving parts
than a standard automotive engine, it is easier to repair and weighs
less.[3][1] However, automotive engines can be repaired by more-common car
mechanics and do not require specialized repair personnel like aircraft
engines do.[5]

Most of the sound produced by an airboat comes from the propeller, although
the engine itself also contributes some noise. Modern airboat designs are
significantly quieter thanks to mufflers and multi-blade carbon-fiber
propellers.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Safety[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Safety")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Air_boat_-
_aft_view.JPG/170px-Air_boat_-_aft_view.JPG)](/wiki/File:Air_boat_-
_aft_view.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Air_boat_-_aft_view.JPG "Enlarge")

Aft view of a safety cage during operation

As with any vehicle, the safety of an airboat is dependent on the training and
skill of its operator and the use of safety features like seat belts and
[flotation devices](/wiki/Flotation_device "Flotation device")/life jackets.
Airboats should only be piloted by trained and qualified operators,[5] and
knowledge of operational safety is essential when operating an airboat.[3]

Over 75 airboat accidents happened in Florida between 2014 and 2017, resulting
in seven deaths and 102 severe injuries. Most (five of seven) deaths were
drownings, and 90 percent of accident victims were not wearing [life
jackets](/wiki/Life_jacket "Life jacket"), even though only 30 percent knew
how to swim. Not wearing a [seat belt](/wiki/Seat_belt "Seat belt") is another
major predictor of injury in an accident: 40 percent of injured victims and
the only two non-drowning fatalities were flung from their seats in the
crashes. The most common injuries suffered in airboat accidents are severe
cuts, bruises, and broken limbs. Other severe injuries are not uncommon: 10
percent of injured people suffered neck and back injuries requiring surgery
and long-term pain medication and another 10 percent suffered traumatic head
and brain injuries.[3]

Most airboat accidents—64%—are the fault of the operator, according to a 2017
analysis by the _[Miami New Times](/wiki/Miami_New_Times "Miami New Times")_ ,
almost always due to one of three factors:[3]

  1. a lack of boating education or training;
  2. a lack of safety equipment, such as seat belts or flotation devices, or a failure to properly use safety equipment;
  3. or reckless behavior, including [drug or alcohol consumption](/wiki/Operating_while_impaired "Operating while impaired") and improper lookout.

The engine and propeller of an airboat are enclosed in a protective metal cage
that prevents objects, such as tree limbs, branches, clothing, beverage
containers, passengers, or wildlife, from coming into contact with the
whirling propeller, which can cause traumatic injury to the operator and
passengers or devastating damage to the vessel.[5] Safety cages do not always
work perfectly, however: people have had their fingers sliced off by airboat
propellers, and tree branches entering safety cages have wrecked airboat
propellers and sprayed the operators and passengers with
[woodchips](/wiki/Woodchips "Woodchips") and other shrapnel.[3]

Airboats are prone to capsizing and sinking because they are top-heavy,
unstable, and extremely shallow draft. This makes them especially dangerous on
the [open sea](/wiki/Open_sea "Open sea") or in [rough](/wiki/Sea_state "Sea
state") or [stormy conditions](/wiki/Violent_storm "Violent storm").[32]
Airboats with a "long-belt gear reduction drive unit" and an automobile engine
avoid these risks because the long belt allows for the engine to be mounted
inside the hull, which lowers the [center of gravity](/wiki/Center_of_gravity
"Center of gravity") and lowers the capsizing risk.[5] Some companies and
organizations, including Airboat West and the [Los Alamos National
Laboratory](/wiki/Los_Alamos_National_Laboratory "Los Alamos National
Laboratory"), have built airboats with low centers of gravity for use in windy
or rough conditions or in rescues with obstacles like low-hanging power
lines.[33] Airboats can also be equipped with auotinflation devices, similar
to car airbags or autoinflating personal life vests, that can reduce the risk
of capsizing.[5]

In 1999 the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service's [National Conservation Training
Center](/wiki/National_Conservation_Training_Center "National Conservation
Training Center"), located in [Shepherdstown, West
Virginia](/wiki/Shepherdstown,_West_Virginia "Shepherdstown, West Virginia"),
produced a 70-minute training video entitled _Airboat Safety – Design-
Operation-Maintenance_ in cooperation with the [U.S. Army Corps of
Engineers](/wiki/U.S._Army_Corps_of_Engineers "U.S. Army Corps of Engineers")
in [Jacksonville, Florida](/wiki/Jacksonville,_Florida "Jacksonville,
Florida"). The video includes an early history of airboats and interviews with
two airboat manufacturers in Florida. It was considered to be the only airboat
video of its kind when it was made and may still be the only one with the
range of airboat subject matter ever produced in the US. Since it was produced
by the federal government of the United States, it is in the [public
domain](/wiki/Public_domain "Public domain"). Five hundred copies of the video
were produced.[34]

### Regulation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Regulation")]

On March 30, 2018 [Gov. Rick Scott](/wiki/Rick_Scott "Rick Scott") of Florida
signed “Ellie’s Law,” which requires operators to complete [CPR](/wiki/CPR
"CPR") instruction and a course on airboats run by the state’s wildlife
commission. The law is named after Elizabeth “Ellie” Goldenberg, who died from
an airboat accident in [Miami-Dade County](/wiki/Miami-Dade_County "Miami-Dade
County") the day after her graduation from college.[35] Beginning July 1,
2019, airboat operators will need to be able to show proof they completed the
training courses. Violations are a misdemeanor offense punishable by up to a
$500 fine.

Florida state law also stipulates that airboats must have an "automotive-style
factory [muffler](/wiki/Muffler "Muffler"), underwater exhaust, or other
manufactured device capable of adequately muffling the sound of the engine
exhaust" and an [international orange](/wiki/International_orange
"International orange") flag that is at least 10" by 12" flying from a mast or
flagpole that is at least 10 feet taller than the lowest point on the boat, in
order to increase visibility and reduce the odds of a collision.[36]

Airboat operators, pilots, or drivers in Florida must be 14 or older.[37]

## Rescue[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Rescue")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3c/FEMA_-_14511_-_Photograph_by_Jocelyn_Augustino_taken_on_08-30-2005_in_Louisiana.jpg/220px-
FEMA_-_14511_-_Photograph_by_Jocelyn_Augustino_taken_on_08-30-2005_in_Louisiana.jpg)](/wiki/File:FEMA_-_14511_-_Photograph_by_Jocelyn_Augustino_taken_on_08-30-2005_in_Louisiana.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:FEMA_-_14511_-_Photograph_by_Jocelyn_Augustino_taken_on_08-30-2005_in_Louisiana.jpg
"Enlarge")

A resident is transported by airboat after Hurricane Katrina

In recent years, airboats have proven indispensable for flood, shallow water,
and ice rescue operations. As a result, they have grown in popularity for
public safety uses.

During the flooding of [New Orleans](/wiki/New_Orleans "New Orleans")
following [Hurricane Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane Katrina"),
August 29, 2005, airboats from across the United States rescued thousands of
flood victims.[38] Thirty airboats crewed by civilian volunteers evacuated
over 1,100 patients and 4,000 medical personnel and family members from four
downtown New Orleans hospitals in less than 36 hours.[39]

Numerous articles have been published in fire-rescue trade journals such as
_[Fire Engineering](/wiki/Fire_Engineering_\(magazine\) "Fire Engineering
\(magazine\)")_ and _[National Fire and Rescue
Magazine](/w/index.php?title=National_Fire_and_Rescue_Magazine&action=edit&redlink=1
"National Fire and Rescue Magazine \(page does not exist\)")_ describing the
advantages, capabilities, and benefits of using airboats for water rescue
operations, and providing in-depth description of actual water rescue
incidents, including the flooding of New Orleans.[39][40][1][5][41][42]

Airboats are particularly effective at water rescues in shallow, marshy, or
icy winter environments. Airboats are partially
[amphibious](/wiki/Amphibious_vehicle "Amphibious vehicle") and can therefore
navigate effectively over obstacles, such as partially submerged buildings and
wreckage or [sea ice](/wiki/Sea_ice "Sea ice"), that would stop a normal boat.
In ice rescues, use of airboats cuts the average rescue time from 45 to 60
minutes to seven to 12 minutes, according to data from Minnesota fire
departments departments. They are also faster, larger, safer, and more durable
than other small boats used in ice rescues.[5]

Though airboats are highly effective at water and ice rescues, airboats and
[helicopters](/wiki/Helicopter "Helicopter") do not work well together. Rotor
wash from low-flying helicopters can push and even capsize airboats. During
post-Katrina rescue operations, a helicopter's rotor wash was reported to have
capsized one airboat, and many airboats were blown into the sides of
buildings, standing utility poles, and bridge pilings by low-flying
helicopters.[39]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/U.S._Customs_and_Border_Protection%2C_Riverine_Unit_Patrols_Rio_Grande_River_Border_in_Air-
Boat.jpg/220px-U.S._Customs_and_Border_Protection%2C_Riverine_Unit_Patrols_Rio_Grande_River_Border_in_Air-
Boat.jpg)](/wiki/File:U.S._Customs_and_Border_Protection,_Riverine_Unit_Patrols_Rio_Grande_River_Border_in_Air-
Boat.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:U.S._Customs_and_Border_Protection,_Riverine_Unit_Patrols_Rio_Grande_River_Border_in_Air-
Boat.jpg "Enlarge")

[U.S. Customs and Border Protection](/wiki/U.S._Customs_and_Border_Protection
"U.S. Customs and Border Protection") patrols the [Rio Grande
River](/wiki/Rio_Grande_River "Rio Grande River") border in an airboat

## Military use[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Airboat&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Military use")]

Airboats are used by various militaries and border patrols around the world as
well as by the [U.S. Coast Guard](/wiki/U.S._Coast_Guard "U.S. Coast
Guard").[43] In addition to the aforementioned uses of airboats by the British
Army in the Mesopotamian Campaign of WWI and by the Soviet Union in the
[Eastern Front](/wiki/Eastern_Front_\(World_War_II\) "Eastern Front \(World
War II\)") of WWII, airboats have been used by the [US Army](/wiki/US_Army "US
Army") and [Iraqi security forces](/wiki/Iraqi_security_forces "Iraqi security
forces") in the Vietnam and Iraq wars, respectively.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a2/MIKE_Force_Aircat.jpg/220px-
MIKE_Force_Aircat.jpg)](/wiki/File:MIKE_Force_Aircat.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MIKE_Force_Aircat.jpg "Enlarge")

US Special Forces Aircat airboat in Vietnam

During the [Vietnam War](/wiki/Vietnam_War "Vietnam War") the [Hurricane
Aircat](/wiki/Hurricane_Aircat "Hurricane Aircat") airboat was used by [U.S.
Special Forces](/wiki/U.S._Special_Forces "U.S. Special Forces") and [South
Vietnamese troops](/wiki/ARVN "ARVN") to patrol riverine and marshy areas
where larger boats could not go.[44] Two of these airboats were also used by
the [Khmer National Navy](/wiki/Khmer_National_Navy "Khmer National Navy")
after they were captured from the U.S. Special Forces by the [People's Army of
Vietnam](/wiki/People%27s_Army_of_Vietnam "People's Army of Vietnam") (PAVN)
in September 1967.[45][46]

Airboats are also used in Texas and Iraq for border patrol.[47] The airboats
used in Iraq were supplied by American companies and assembled in Iraq by
American civilian contractors, and they are used by both American and Iraqi
forces to patrol the Tigris and Euphrates rivers, the
[marshes](/wiki/Mesopotamian_Marshes "Mesopotamian Marshes") of southeastern
Iraq, and the [Shatt al-Arab](/wiki/Shatt_al-Arab "Shatt al-Arab") waterway,
the latter two of which include parts of the Iran-Iraq border.[48] Modern
Iraqi military airboats are 18 feet (5.5 m) long, powered by 454 hp engines
hooked up to 78-inch (2.0 m) Whirlwind propellers, and armed with
[M240](/wiki/M240 "M240") crew-served machine guns.[48] The Nov/Dec 2007 issue
of _[Airboating
Magazine](/w/index.php?title=Airboating_Magazine&action=edit&redlink=1
"Airboating Magazine \(page does not exist\)")_ had an article on airboats
used in Vietnam and in Iraq and has had numerous articles on airboats used by
U.S Coast Guard and other state and county
[EMS](/wiki/Emergency_medical_services "Emergency medical services") units for
rescue of [ice fisherman](/wiki/Ice_fishing "Ice fishing") and rescue in
floods or after hurricanes.

In 2013 the [Iraqi Ministry of Oil](/wiki/Ministry_of_Oil_\(Iraq\) "Ministry
of Oil \(Iraq\)") purchased 20 airboats for use as personnel transport,
patrol, and cable laying and light cargo boats in the rivers and marshes of
Iraq.[7]

section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** In early [aviation](/wiki/Aviation "Aviation") history the term _airboat_ was applied to [seaplanes](/wiki/Seaplane "Seaplane") or [flying boats](/wiki/Flying_boat "Flying boat"), i.e.[amphibian aircraft](/wiki/Amphibian_aircraft "Amphibian aircraft") capable of taking off and landing on water surfaces. Early airboats were known as "hydroglisseurs" (airboat in [French](/wiki/French_language "French language"), lit. "water slider"), hydroplanes, hydrofoils, or other names. See e.g. _Flying_ [Volume 4](https://books.google.com/books?id=7h5EAQAAMAAJ) (1915-1916) and Cercle du Mononautisme Classique [Archives historiques](http://www.cmc-retronautisme.fr/librairie.hydroglisseurs.htm) (in French).
  2. **Jump up ^** The source cited states the price of an airboat as $25,000 to $40,000 in 2004, which is equal to between $33,000 and $53,000 in 2018 dollars.
  3. **Jump up ^** Lambert refers to their manufacturer, the _De Lambert_ company of France, and "Hydro-Glisseur" means "airboat" in [French](/wiki/French_language "French language").
